Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

div.head: Bekanntmachung

Alexandrien, den 16 Marz, 1905.
Der Kaiserliche Konsul,
Von Humboldt

div.head: Cairene Society
div.p: Some time has elapsed since Cairo was termed 'the Grave of the Soul,' and before attending the obsequies of our own morals, we wish to flute a wild carol. The division of upper Cairene society into hostile circles is a touching tribute to its own vitality, and day by day the lines of each become more clearly marked. That these circles are fully outlined

div.head: Cairene Society
div.p: is obvious. In many cases restless spirits may be seen who would intrude into an alien circle, if their own efforts could give them sufficient momentum. If it were ordained that these circles could be self-supporting, lighted with a kindled flame of brotherhood and Christian feel-ing, each might revolve in hostile ecstacy. But the demands of actual life are constantly bringing these circles into rude conflict, in which sanctimonious tact alone prevents a sharer shock. The construction of dinner parties is a severe trial of calculating powers, as the position of each entity must be established. When contamination and moral repining result from a confusion of circles, when the enemy of a circlr is this far outcast to all within in, surely the irony is grim. Many a tear has bedewed this fair city, many a bitter word has floated into the genial air, through a mistaken introduction and a momentary slip. 'Hinc illae lacrimae.'

The strain of the hidden warfare is intense. Is our natural intelligence so great that it can be appied undimished to these tortuous problems ? By all means let us cut ourselves off from inferior circles, but let there not be dissensions in the higher spheres; let us be rude to each in a cheerful and brotherly spirit, neither sparing not looking for mercy. Let us not twist our tongues and gibe unseen, but rather exchange grimaces before all men. Lus us all race and shriek together, when once admitted to these higher circles. Let us not cluck and chatter in chosen haunts, but rather flutter, however helplessly, along the high-ways of existance. It is not a question of frantic affections and wild enthusiasms but of rational disinterestedness and fellow-feeling. Our doors need not be open to all, but those who enter need not clothe themselves with smooth veneer and rigid rectitude of mein. Use the pitchfork only when nature is impossible. "Know thyself and thou thyself shalt know."

div.head: Turkish Reform and Finance
div.p: The Porte has just informed the Powers of Europe,through the medium of the Austrian and Russian Ambassadors, that the partial execution of the reforms demanded has caused a deficit in the finances of Macedonie. It, therefore, proposes to raise the Customs duties from eight to eleven per cent, and Austria and Russia have agreed to consent to this is the Porte will accept the scheme of financial reform which was put forward, and will employ the money as the Powers desire.If it is once realised in Europe that finance is the key of the whole Near Eastern Ques-tion it is possible that some advance may be made. It is the miserable state of the Otto-man treasury which has brough about the whole affair, and the extortions of the tax collector are the root of all evil and dis-content. The Governer of a province has to remit a certain sum to Constantinople every year, and also to pay his oficials and his soldiers, and,what is moe important to him, himself. He farms out the rvenues of his province to men who exact far more than they ought, and who make a very good thing out of it. The Vali Pasha sends the necessary amount to Constantinople, helps himself liberally, and assigns the rest to his officers and officials, the troops, as a rule, coming off with next to nothing. The conse-quence is that two parties are dissatisfied; the peasants, who are exorbitantly fleeced, and the petty officials and soldiers who cannot get their pay. If once the Turkish finances were, like the Egyptian, placed on a sound basis, all this discontent would dis-appear. But as this would run counter to the policy of Austria and Russia, the needed reform will never take place.

Londres et Tripoli; 4 j., 3/4, vap. angl. Kaffir Prince, cap. Wright, ton. 1402, à Grace & Co.
Syrie et Port-Saïd; 16 h., vap. ang. El Kahira, cap. Silvestri, ton. 848, à la Khedivial Mail.
Cardiff; 14 j. 1/2, vap. ang. Chiverstone, cap. Dwyer, ton. 1889, à ordre.
Beyrouth et Port-Saïd ; 16 h., vapour français Sénégal, cap. Vincenti, ton. 2,235, aux Messageries Maritimes.
DÉPARTS
Pirée et Constantinople : vap. ang. Ismailieh, cap. Gatteschi.
Hull; vap. ang. Lorenzo, cap. Wing.
Jaffa; vap. ott, Marigo, cap. Cofupandelis, sur lest.

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le marché a ouvert en pleine hausse, tant à cause de l'Amérique que sur les gros embarquements. Beaucoup d'affaires.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Très fermes. Premier cours P.T. 63.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905

Safesta and most Gentle Medicine for Infants, Children, Delicate Females, and the Sickness of Pregnancy.

div.head: Orenstein & Koppel, Ltd.
div.p: Capital 10,000,000 Frs.
Purveyors to H.H. the Khedive.
Portable and permanent railways. Passenger and goods cars.
Tipping and platform waggons for all purposes. Locomotives from 10-400 H.P.
Large stocks of rails, trucks and locomotives always kept in Alexandria.
Sole Agents for Egypt and Sudan of:--
COMPTOIR METALLURGIQUE EGYPTIEN
Bridges and iron frame works.
HUMBOLDT ENGINEERING WORKS CO
KALK, NEAR COLOGNE.
Steam engines, Boilers, complete installations for Factories.
R. HORNSBY & SONS, LTD., Grantham (England).
Fixed and Portable oil engines.
KIRCHNER & CO., Leipzig.
Wood working machinery.
CARL MEISSNER, Hamburg.
Oil motor boats and launches.
ENGLISH AND AMERICAN SYSTEMS OF STEAM PLOUGHING ENGINES TO PLOUGH 8 TO 20 FEDDANS PER DAY
Offices:
Cairo: 24 Kasr-el-Nil Street, opposite Bank of Egypt. P.O.B. 690. Telephone No. 139.
Alexandria: 29, Cherif Pasha Street. Telephone No. 661.

are always possible at a minimum cost provided you use
FRESKEL (REGD.)

Thos. Hinselwood & Co., Alexandria

div.head:
Dr. Le Clerc's
Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
Dr. Le Clerc's Soap.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.
